tags.bio:
Adrian McKinty grew up in Carrickfergus, Northern Ireland and since 2008 has lived in Melbourne, Australia.

After studying philosophy at Oxford University he moved to New York City, working in bars, bookstores, building sites and finally the basement stacks of the Columbia University Medical School Library. In 2000 he relocated to Denver, Colorado where he taught high school English and began writing fiction.

McKinty's latest novel is I Hear the Sirens in the Street (Serpent's Tail). His blog is here and he tweets at @AdrianMcKinty.

tags.bio:
Jo Shapcott teaches on the MA in creative writing at Royal Holloway College, University of London and is also visiting professor in poetry at the University of Newcastle and the University of the Arts, London. She is currently president of The Poetry Society.

Her poetry collections, including Elecroplating the Baby, Phrase Book and My Life Asleep have won numerous awards including the Commonwealth poetry prize for best first collection, and the Forward poetry prize for best collection. She has also won the National Poetry Competition twice. Her next book, Of Mutability, is due in 2010.

webTitle: Guardian Camera Club: David Collier's portfolio

fields.standfirst:
A review of David Collier's portfolio.

These claustrophobic underwater images are striking and simply impressive. The dark red colours of 'Heather at Maroubra' are rather grim; the huge graininess of 'Wuthering Depths' gives an impressionistic feel, the figure is perfectly placed in the frame. Much more uplifting is 'Water line', that small part of sky makes for a much lighter feeling image. 'Jane at Bondi' is a photo seen through a glass darkly; 'Afternoon rays' is maybe somewhat too literal visually and less interesting than the rest. The air bubble in 'Karen' and those incredible colours make a perfect underwater photo; this is a very interesting set, well executed but with sufficient mystery to really engage
fields.headline: Guardian Camera Club: David Collier's portfolio
fields.trailText: A review of David Collier's portfolio

webTitle: MS St. Louis - picture of the day

fields.standfirst: A photographic highlight selected by the picture desk. The MS St. Louis, a German ocean liner carrying over 937 Jewish refugees, was denied entry to the United States on this day in 1939. It had already been turned away from Cuba and would later be refused entry to Canada. When the ship returned to Europe it had been at sea for over a month. The passengers were finally given refuge in various European countries, but it is estimated that approximately a quarter of the passengers died in concentration camps.
fields.headline: MS St. Louis - picture of the day
